dc:description: There have been three studies published implicating NRAS with Noonan syndrome with multiple lentigines (NSML), however only one unique variant has been identified. The p.Gly60Glu variant has been identified in de novo cases, segregated in one family with disease, and individuals with unknown origin who possess clinical features of NSML (Ekvall et al., 2015; Kraoua et al., 2012). This variant has also been found in individuals without multiple lentigines with clinical features of NS (Cirstea et al., 2010). Of note, one individual with the p.Gly13Asp variant possessed the juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia phenotype in addition to clinical features of NSML (De Filippi et al., 2009). This case was not scored, but should be noted as a possible additional phenotype. The NRAS gene is also located in the Ras/MAPK pathway, which is associated with the NSML phenotype (Aoki et al., 2016; Rauen, 2013). In summary, the evidence supporting NRASâ€™s association with NSML is Limited, however the presence of multiple lentigines makes this evidence distinct from the other Noonan cases. Of note, NRAS has also been classified as Definitive in association with NS and as Limited in association with Costello syndrome and cardiofaciocutaneous syndrome. The ClinGen RASopathy Expert Panel found no evidence associating NRAS with NS-like disorder with loose anagen hair. This curation was approved by the ClinGen RASopathy Gene Curation Expert Panel on 5/30/18 (SOP Version 5).

evidence.dc:description:
This case also presented with ML without leukemia or cancer and therefore is more in line with NSML than JMML. Can be scored
Variant is present in 1 European allele in gnomAD.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: plyhydramnios, no congential heart defects or rhythm disturbance, typical facial features, short stature, no macrocephaly, pterygium, mildly depressed thorax, easy bruising, no cryptorchidism, opthalmological problems not present, mild motor delay/hypotonia, speech delay, dyscalculy, no hair abnormalities, lentigines present, no palpebral ptosis, yes inguinal herina, and scoliosis

evidence.dc:description: This individual had  a variant segregate from her affected father to her causing NSML in both individuals. A RASopathy panel was conducted and the p.G60E (a recurrant NRAS variant) was identified in the family. This variant has been found in de novo cases as well.

evidence.rdfs:label: Ekvall_1
evidence.detectionMethod: inherited from father who also had signs of NSML
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
"clinical diagnosis
of Noonan syndrome (NS) at the age of 4 years
because of growth retardation, cardiomyopathy and facial
features. She is the only child of non-related parents. Partial GH deficiency, normal psychomotor devleopment but has slight attention dficit problems"
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
"The index patient was analyzed for variants in all coding
exons and exon-intron boundaries of NF1 (NM_00
0267.3), PTPN11 (NM_002834), SOS1 (NM_005633),
CBL (NM_005188), BRAF (NM_004333), RAF1 (NM_00
2880), SHOC2 (NM_007373), MAP2K2 (NM_030662),
MAP2K1 (NM_002755), SPRED1 (NM_152594), NRAS
(NM_002524), HRAS (NM_005343) and KRAS (NM_00
4985)"

evidence.dc:description:
Variant is present in 1 European allele in gnomAD.
This patient was diagnosed with JMML therefore the case cannot count even though they may have lentigines.

evidence.rdfs:label: Filippi_1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
"high forehead, bilateral epicanthal folds, long
eyebrows, low nasal bridge and slightly low-set ears. Clinically diagnosed with juvenile myelomonocytic leukaemia (JMML)"
evidence.previousTestingDescription: sequencing of NRAS, unclear what other genes were sequenced

evidence.dc:description:
This individual seems to have clinical features more in line with NS than JMML as they do not have Leukemia or cancer. Therefore, this de novo occurance can be scored.
Variant is present in 1 European allele in gnomAD.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: pyelectasis, PS heart defect, short stature, pectus excavatum, pterygium, no opthalmoloigcal problems, motor delay/hypotonia, mental dev not assessed, curly hair, lentigines, no cancer or leukemia, palpebral ptosis, unilateral pyelectasis

evidence.dc:description: These genes are all historically associated with the RAS/MAPK patwhay and therefore there is a link between this gene and NSML
evidence.rdfs:label: NRAS RAS/MAPK associatin
